name: SQL Mastery
description: Complete SQL course covering fundamentals to advanced concepts including MySQL, database design, performance optimization, and LeetCode problem solving

topics.name: Introduction to SQL
learningTip: SQL is the universal language of databases - every developer needs it
It's DECLARATIVE: describe WHAT you want, not HOW to get it
The database optimizer decides the most efficient execution plan
Master SQL once, apply it everywhere: MySQL, PostgreSQL, SQLite, Oracle
mustNotMiss: SQL keywords are case-insensitive (SELECT = select), but UPPERCASE is convention
String literals use single quotes: 'hello', not double quotes
Comments: -- single line, /* multi line */
Semicolon terminates statements - required in scripts, optional in single queries
topics.description: Introduction to SQL

topics.name: Installing MySQL (Mac & Windows)
learningTip: Local installation gives you a playground for experimentation
MySQL Workbench provides GUI, but learn command line too
Docker is excellent for quick, isolated database setups
Practice with real databases, not just reading
mustNotMiss: Default port: 3306. Root password set during installation
mysql -u root -p to connect via command line
SHOW DATABASES; to see available databases
USE database_name; to switch to a database
topics.description: Master Installing MySQL (Mac & Windows) for effective SQL queries

topics.name: Creating the Databases
learningTip: Create sample database with realistic data for practice
Understand the schema: tables, columns, relationships
ERD (Entity Relationship Diagram) visualizes structure
Import sample datasets for realistic query practice
mustNotMiss: CREATE DATABASE db_name; creates new database
DROP DATABASE db_name; deletes entire database - DANGEROUS
SOURCE /path/to/script.sql; runs SQL script file
SHOW TABLES; lists all tables in current database
topics.description: Master Creating the Databases for effective SQL queries

topics.name: What You'll Learn & Learning Paths
learningTip: SQL mastery builds layer by layer: SELECT → JOINs → Aggregation → Subqueries
Each concept builds on previous ones - don't skip ahead
Practice with LeetCode SQL problems for interview prep
Understand execution order: FROM → WHERE → GROUP BY → HAVING → SELECT → ORDER BY
mustNotMiss: Execution order is NOT the same as writing order
WHERE filters rows BEFORE grouping, HAVING filters AFTER
Aliases defined in SELECT aren't available in WHERE (not yet evaluated)
This execution order explains 90% of 'why doesn't this work' questions
topics.description: Master What You'll Learn & Learning Paths for effective SQL queries

defaultSyllabus.name: Retrieving Data From a Single Table

topics.name: The SELECT Statement
learningTip: SELECT is the foundation - every data retrieval starts here
Column selection determines what you see and network transfer size
Aliases make output readable: SELECT price * 1.1 AS discounted_price
DISTINCT removes duplicates but has performance cost
mustNotMiss: SELECT * is lazy and inefficient - always specify needed columns
Column order in SELECT determines output column order
Expressions allowed: SELECT first_name, last_name, salary * 12 AS annual_salary
NULL in expressions propagates: 5 + NULL = NULL
topics.description: Master the The SELECT Statement for data retrieval

topics.name: The SELECT Clause
learningTip: SELECT clause specifies output columns and expressions
Can include calculations, function calls, and constants
Alias with AS for readable output (AS is optional but recommended)
Expression results computed for each row
mustNotMiss: Arithmetic: +, -, *, /, % (modulo). Division by zero gives NULL in MySQL
Concatenation: CONCAT(first_name, ' ', last_name) AS full_name
DISTINCT applies to entire row, not single column
SELECT DISTINCT col1, col2 returns unique combinations
topics.description: Master the The SELECT Clause for data retrieval

topics.name: The WHERE Clause
learningTip: WHERE filters rows BEFORE any grouping or aggregation
Uses comparison operators: =, <>, <, >, <=, >=, LIKE, IN, BETWEEN
NULL requires special handling: IS NULL, not = NULL
Index usage depends heavily on WHERE conditions
mustNotMiss: = for equality, <> or != for not equal (prefer <>)
String comparison is case-insensitive in MySQL by default
Dates compare naturally: WHERE order_date > '2023-01-01'
Cannot use aggregate functions in WHERE - use HAVING instead
topics.description: Filter data using The WHERE Clause

topics.name: The AND, OR and NOT Operators
learningTip: AND, OR, NOT combine conditions logically
Precedence: NOT > AND > OR - use parentheses for clarity
Short-circuit evaluation: AND stops at first false, OR at first true
Complex conditions benefit from parentheses even when not required
mustNotMiss: WHERE active = TRUE AND (role = 'admin' OR role = 'manager')
NOT negates: NOT IN, NOT LIKE, NOT BETWEEN, IS NOT NULL
X AND NULL = NULL (unknown), X OR NULL depends on X
Always use parentheses in complex conditions - prevents bugs
topics.description: Using The AND, OR and NOT Operators for conditional filtering

topics.name: The IN Operator
learningTip: IN checks if value matches any in a list - cleaner than multiple ORs
List can be explicit values or subquery result
NOT IN excludes matching values
More readable and often more efficient than OR chains
mustNotMiss: WHERE state IN ('CA', 'NY', 'TX') vs state = 'CA' OR state = 'NY' OR ...
IN with subquery: WHERE customer_id IN (SELECT customer_id FROM orders)
WARNING: NOT IN with NULL in list returns empty! Use NOT EXISTS instead
Performance: IN may be optimized to binary search if indexed
topics.description: Using The IN Operator for conditional filtering

topics.name: The BETWEEN Operator
learningTip: BETWEEN is inclusive on both ends: BETWEEN a AND b means >= a AND <= b
Cleaner than separate >= and <= conditions
Works with numbers, dates, and strings
NOT BETWEEN excludes the range
mustNotMiss: BETWEEN 10 AND 20 includes both 10 and 20
Date range: BETWEEN '2023-01-01' AND '2023-12-31' includes both dates
Order matters: BETWEEN small AND large, not BETWEEN large AND small
For exclusive bounds, use < and > instead
topics.description: Using The BETWEEN Operator for conditional filtering

topics.name: The LIKE Operator
learningTip: LIKE enables pattern matching with wildcards
% matches any sequence of characters (including empty)
_ matches exactly one character
Essential for search functionality
mustNotMiss: '%apple%' - contains 'apple' anywhere
'apple%' - starts with 'apple'
'%apple' - ends with 'apple'
'_a%' - second character is 'a'
Case sensitivity depends on collation - MySQL default is case-insensitive
topics.description: Using The LIKE Operator for conditional filtering

topics.name: The REGEXP Operator
learningTip: REGEXP provides full regular expression power
More flexible than LIKE but often slower
Use for complex pattern matching requirements
Syntax follows POSIX regex standards
mustNotMiss: ^ start, $ end: '^hello$' matches exactly 'hello'
| alternation: 'mac|linux' matches either
[abc] character class, [a-z] range, [^abc] negation
REGEXP_LIKE() function for explicit boolean return in some databases
topics.description: Using The REGEXP Operator for conditional filtering

topics.name: The IS NULL Operator
learningTip: NULL means missing/unknown - it's NOT zero, NOT empty string
Cannot compare with =, must use IS NULL or IS NOT NULL
Any comparison with NULL returns NULL (unknown), not true or false
NULL handling is crucial for correct queries
mustNotMiss: NULL = NULL returns NULL (unknown), not TRUE!
WHERE column IS NULL to find missing values
COALESCE(column, default) returns first non-null value
IFNULL(column, default) MySQL-specific version of COALESCE for two args
topics.description: Using The IS NULL Operator for conditional filtering

topics.name: The ORDER BY Clause
learningTip: ORDER BY sorts result set before returning
ASC (ascending) is default, DESC for descending
Can sort by multiple columns with different directions
Sorting happens after filtering but before LIMIT
mustNotMiss: ORDER BY col1 ASC, col2 DESC - sort by col1 first, then col2
Can use column position: ORDER BY 1, 2 (first and second columns)
Can use expressions: ORDER BY first_name || last_name
NULLs sort first in ASC, last in DESC (in MySQL)
topics.description: Master The ORDER BY Clause for effective SQL queries

topics.name: The LIMIT Clause
learningTip: LIMIT restricts number of rows returned
Essential for pagination and top-N queries
OFFSET specifies starting point for pagination
ORDER BY + LIMIT is the top-N pattern
mustNotMiss: LIMIT 10 returns first 10 rows
LIMIT 10 OFFSET 20 returns rows 21-30 (skip first 20)
Alternative syntax: LIMIT 20, 10 means LIMIT 10 OFFSET 20
Without ORDER BY, results are unpredictable - always use with ORDER BY
topics.description: Master The LIMIT Clause for effective SQL queries

topics.name: Inner Joins
learningTip: INNER JOIN returns only rows with matches in BOTH tables
This is the most common join type in practice
Think of it as finding the INTERSECTION
Must specify join condition with ON clause
mustNotMiss: SELECT * FROM orders o INNER JOIN customers c ON o.customer_id = c.customer_id
Without ON clause: Cartesian product (every row × every row) - usually wrong
Table aliases (o, c) make queries readable and shorter
Join on foreign key = primary key is the standard pattern
topics.description: Combine data from multiple tables using Inner Joins

topics.name: Joining Across Databases
learningTip: Can join tables from different databases using db.table syntax
Cross-database joins require proper permissions
Useful for data integration and migration scenarios
Performance may suffer due to network overhead
mustNotMiss: SELECT * FROM db1.orders o JOIN db2.customers c ON o.customer_id = c.id
Fully qualified: database.table.column
Indexes on join columns are critical for performance
Consider data locality when designing cross-database queries
topics.description: Combine data from multiple tables using Joining Across Databases

topics.name: Self Joins

practiceQuestions.name: Employees Earning More Than Their Managers

learningTip: Table joined to itself - requires aliases to distinguish copies
Common for hierarchical data (employee-manager)
Also for comparing rows within same table
Think of it as two copies of the same table
mustNotMiss: SELECT e.name, m.name AS manager FROM employees e JOIN employees m ON e.manager_id = m.employee_id
Different aliases (e, m) distinguish the two 'copies'
Hierarchical queries: who reports to whom?
Combine with LEFT JOIN to include root elements (no manager)
topics.description: Combine data from multiple tables using Self Joins

topics.name: Joining Multiple Tables
learningTip: Chain multiple JOINs for complex relationships
Each JOIN adds another table to the result
Read as: start with first table, add second, add third...
Order can affect performance but not results
mustNotMiss: SELECT * FROM orders o JOIN customers c ON o.customer_id = c.id JOIN shippers s ON o.shipper_id = s.id
Each JOIN has its own ON condition
Can mix JOIN types: INNER JOIN then LEFT JOIN
More tables = more complexity - consider views for common patterns
topics.description: Combine data from multiple tables using Joining Multiple Tables

topics.name: Compound Join Conditions
learningTip: Some relationships require matching on multiple columns: ON a.col1 = b.col1 AND a.col2 = b.col2.
mustNotMiss: Composite keys: When primary key is multiple columns, join must match all parts. Common in many-to-many tables with additional attributes. Ensure all join columns are indexed together (composite index).
topics.description: Combine data from multiple tables using Compound Join Conditions

topics.name: Implicit Join Syntax
learningTip: Old-style join syntax: FROM a, b WHERE a.key = b.key. Equivalent to INNER JOIN but less clear.
mustNotMiss: Avoid implicit joins - they're error-prone. Easy to forget the WHERE condition, creating unintended Cartesian products. Modern SQL prefers explicit JOIN syntax for clarity and to separate join conditions from filter conditions.
topics.description: Combine data from multiple tables using Implicit Join Syntax

topics.name: Outer Joins
learningTip: LEFT JOIN keeps ALL rows from left table, NULLs for non-matches
RIGHT JOIN keeps ALL rows from right table
Use when you want records that DON'T have matches too
Critical for 'find records without matches' queries
mustNotMiss: LEFT JOIN: all customers, even those without orders (orders columns = NULL)
SELECT * FROM customers c LEFT JOIN orders o ON c.id = o.customer_id
Find unmatched: WHERE o.id IS NULL gives customers with no orders
IMPORTANT: WHERE on outer-joined table converts to INNER JOIN! Use ON instead
topics.description: Combine data from multiple tables using Outer Joins

topics.name: Outer Join Between Multiple Tables
learningTip: Chaining outer joins is tricky. Each subsequent join operates on the previous result. NULLs from earlier joins affect later conditions.
mustNotMiss: Common mistake: Putting a filter on the outer-joined table in WHERE instead of ON. 'WHERE right_table.col = value' converts LEFT JOIN to INNER JOIN (NULL rows eliminated). Put such conditions in the ON clause to preserve LEFT JOIN behavior.
topics.description: Combine data from multiple tables using Outer Join Between Multiple Tables

topics.name: Self Outer Joins
learningTip: Self join with LEFT/RIGHT for hierarchical queries with root nodes
Employees including those with no manager
Products including those with no parent category
Combines self-join and outer join concepts
mustNotMiss: SELECT e.name, m.name AS manager FROM employees e LEFT JOIN employees m ON e.manager_id = m.id
CEO/root node has NULL manager_id - LEFT JOIN keeps them
Can find root: WHERE m.id IS NULL
Can count subordinates: GROUP BY m.id with COUNT(e.id)
topics.description: Combine data from multiple tables using Self Outer Joins

topics.name: The USING Clause
learningTip: USING simplifies joins when column names match exactly
Shorthand for ON a.col = b.col
Cleaner syntax when naming conventions are consistent
Common in well-designed schemas
mustNotMiss: JOIN customers USING (customer_id) instead of ON orders.customer_id = customers.customer_id
Column name must be identical in both tables
Can have multiple: USING (col1, col2)
USING column appears only once in result (unlike ON)
topics.description: Master The USING Clause for effective SQL queries

topics.name: Natural Joins
learningTip: NATURAL JOIN automatically joins on ALL columns with matching names
Convenient but DANGEROUS - implicit behavior can cause bugs
Adding a column can silently change join behavior
Avoid in production code - prefer explicit USING or ON
mustNotMiss: NATURAL JOIN finds all matching column names automatically
If tables share 'id' column, it joins on 'id' - probably not what you want!
Schema changes can break queries silently
Use for quick exploration only, never in production
topics.description: Combine data from multiple tables using Natural Joins

topics.name: Cross Joins
learningTip: CROSS JOIN produces Cartesian product: every row × every row
Rarely needed but has use cases: generating combinations
Result size = rows1 × rows2 - can be huge!
Explicit CROSS JOIN documents intent
mustNotMiss: SELECT * FROM sizes CROSS JOIN colors - all size-color combinations
Implicit: SELECT * FROM a, b (old syntax)
10 rows × 10 rows = 100 rows; 1000 × 1000 = 1 million rows
Use case: generating test data, calendar tables, combination grids
topics.description: Combine data from multiple tables using Cross Joins

topics.name: Unions

practiceQuestions.name: Managers with at Least 5 Direct Reports

learningTip: UNION combines result sets vertically (stacks rows)
Column count and types must match between queries
UNION removes duplicates, UNION ALL keeps all
Use for combining similar data from multiple sources
mustNotMiss: SELECT name FROM customers UNION SELECT name FROM suppliers
UNION ALL is faster (no duplicate check)
Column names come from first SELECT
ORDER BY applies to final result, goes at the end
topics.description: Master Unions for effective SQL queries

topics.name: Column Attributes
learningTip: Column definitions include: name, data type, constraints, defaults
Constraints enforce data integrity at database level
NOT NULL prevents missing values, DEFAULT provides fallback
Understanding column attributes is foundation for table design
mustNotMiss: VARCHAR(n) for variable-length strings, CHAR(n) for fixed-length
INT, BIGINT, DECIMAL(p,s) for numbers. DECIMAL for precise money!
DATETIME includes time, DATE is date only, TIMESTAMP auto-updates
AUTO_INCREMENT for auto-generated IDs (primary keys)
topics.description: Master Column Attributes for effective SQL queries

topics.name: Inserting a Row
learningTip: INSERT adds new rows to a table
Specify columns or rely on column order (column list is safer)
DEFAULT keyword uses column's default value
NULL for nullable columns when value is unknown
mustNotMiss: INSERT INTO table (col1, col2) VALUES ('val1', 'val2')
Auto-increment columns: omit or use DEFAULT
Order must match between column list and values
Insert fails if constraints violated (NOT NULL, UNIQUE, FOREIGN KEY)
topics.description: Data manipulation with Inserting a Row

topics.name: Inserting Multiple Rows
learningTip: Single INSERT with multiple value sets is faster than multiple INSERTs
Reduces network roundtrips and transaction overhead
Batch inserts are essential for data loading
Consider LOAD DATA for very large imports
mustNotMiss: INSERT INTO table (col1, col2) VALUES ('a', 1), ('b', 2), ('c', 3)
All rows inserted in single transaction (all succeed or all fail)
MySQL limit: max_allowed_packet affects maximum batch size
For millions of rows, use LOAD DATA INFILE
topics.description: Data manipulation with Inserting Multiple Rows

topics.name: Inserting Hierarchical Rows
learningTip: Insert parent first, then child rows with parent's ID
Use LAST_INSERT_ID() to get auto-generated parent ID
Foreign key relationships require this order
Transactions ensure parent and children succeed together
mustNotMiss: INSERT INTO orders (...); INSERT INTO order_items (order_id, ...) VALUES (LAST_INSERT_ID(), ...);
LAST_INSERT_ID() returns last auto-increment value in current session
Wrap in transaction: START TRANSACTION; ... COMMIT;
Foreign key violation if parent doesn't exist
topics.description: Data manipulation with Inserting Hierarchical Rows

topics.name: Creating a Copy of a Table
learningTip: INSERT ... SELECT copies data from one table to another
Create table structure with CREATE TABLE ... AS SELECT ...
Useful for backups, data transformation, archiving
Subquery in INSERT provides source data
mustNotMiss: INSERT INTO table2 SELECT * FROM table1 WHERE condition
CREATE TABLE new_table AS SELECT * FROM old_table (copies structure and data)
CREATE TABLE AS SELECT doesn't copy indexes or constraints!
Add WHERE clause to copy subset
topics.description: Master Creating a Copy of a Table for effective SQL queries

topics.name: Updating a Single Row
learningTip: UPDATE modifies existing rows - WHERE clause is critical
Without WHERE, ALL rows are updated - very dangerous!
Can update multiple columns in single statement
Use SELECT first to verify which rows will be affected
mustNotMiss: UPDATE table SET col1 = val1, col2 = val2 WHERE id = 1
ALWAYS include WHERE unless you want to update all rows
Safe practice: SELECT first, then change to UPDATE
SET can use expressions: SET price = price * 1.1
topics.description: Master Updating a Single Row for effective SQL queries

topics.name: Updating Multiple Rows
learningTip: WHERE condition determines which rows get updated
Can use IN, BETWEEN, LIKE in WHERE for multiple rows
All matching rows updated in single operation
Consider impact on foreign key relationships
mustNotMiss: UPDATE products SET price = price * 1.1 WHERE category_id = 5
All products in category 5 get 10% price increase
LIMIT can restrict number of rows updated
Triggers may fire for each row - consider performance
topics.description: Master Updating Multiple Rows for effective SQL queries

topics.name: Using Subqueries in Updates
learningTip: Subquery in UPDATE provides dynamic values or conditions
Common pattern: update based on aggregation from another table
Can use in SET clause or WHERE clause
Powerful for derived values
mustNotMiss: UPDATE orders SET discount = (SELECT max_discount FROM customers WHERE ...) WHERE customer_id = ...
UPDATE in SET: dynamic value from subquery
UPDATE with WHERE subquery: UPDATE orders SET status = 'archived' WHERE customer_id IN (SELECT id FROM customers WHERE inactive = 1)
Watch for performance with correlated subqueries
topics.description: Data manipulation with Using Subqueries in Updates

topics.name: Deleting Rows
learningTip: DELETE removes rows permanently - WHERE is critical
Without WHERE, ALL rows deleted - CANNOT be undone!
Foreign key constraints may prevent deletion
TRUNCATE is faster for deleting all rows but resets auto-increment
mustNotMiss: DELETE FROM table WHERE id = 1
DELETE without WHERE deletes ALL rows - DANGEROUS
TRUNCATE TABLE table - faster, resets auto-increment, no row-by-row triggers
ON DELETE CASCADE: child rows deleted automatically with parent
topics.description: Master Deleting Rows for effective SQL queries

topics.name: Restoring the Databases
learningTip: Re-import from backup SQL files. Understand mysqldump for backup and mysql for restore.
mustNotMiss: Restore command: mysql -u user -p database < backup.sql. For large databases, use --single-transaction flag during dump to avoid locking. Test restores regularly - backups are useless if you can't restore.
topics.description: Master Restoring the Databases for effective SQL queries

topics.name: Aggregate Functions
learningTip: Aggregate functions summarize multiple rows into single value
COUNT, SUM, AVG, MIN, MAX are the core five
Often used with GROUP BY for grouping
NULL handling varies by function
mustNotMiss: COUNT(*) counts all rows, COUNT(column) counts non-NULL values only
SUM, AVG ignore NULL values (AVG of 10, NULL, 20 = 15, not 10)
COUNT(DISTINCT column) for unique value count
MIN/MAX work on strings too (alphabetical order)
topics.description: SQL functions for Aggregate Functions

topics.name: The GROUP BY Clause

practiceQuestions.name: Customer Placing the Largest Number of Orders

learningTip: GROUP BY groups rows with same values into summary rows
Each group produces one output row
SELECT can only include grouped columns or aggregate functions
Think of it as creating 'buckets' by some criteria
mustNotMiss: SELECT customer_id, COUNT(*) FROM orders GROUP BY customer_id
Every non-aggregate column in SELECT must be in GROUP BY
Can group by multiple columns: GROUP BY year, month
Execution order: WHERE → GROUP BY → HAVING → SELECT
topics.description: Summarize and aggregate data using The GROUP BY Clause

topics.name: The HAVING Clause
learningTip: HAVING filters GROUPS, WHERE filters ROWS
Applied AFTER GROUP BY, unlike WHERE
Can use aggregate functions in HAVING
Use for conditions on aggregated values
mustNotMiss: SELECT customer_id, COUNT(*) as order_count FROM orders GROUP BY customer_id HAVING COUNT(*) > 5
WHERE filters before grouping (on individual rows)
HAVING filters after grouping (on group results)
For non-aggregate conditions, prefer WHERE (more efficient)
topics.description: Summarize and aggregate data using The HAVING Clause

topics.name: The ROLLUP Operator
learningTip: ROLLUP generates subtotals and grand total automatically
Creates hierarchical summary from left to right
Adds extra rows with NULL representing 'all'
Great for reports with totals at multiple levels
mustNotMiss: GROUP BY col1, col2 WITH ROLLUP adds: subtotal per col1, grand total
NULL appears in place of 'all values'
Use GROUPING() function to identify rollup rows
CUBE gives all possible combinations (more than ROLLUP)
topics.description: Using The ROLLUP Operator for conditional filtering

topics.name: Introduction to Subqueries
learningTip: Subquery = query inside another query
Inner query runs first, result used by outer query
Can appear in SELECT, FROM, WHERE, HAVING
Essential for complex data retrieval
mustNotMiss: WHERE price > (SELECT AVG(price) FROM products) - scalar subquery
Subquery must be enclosed in parentheses
Three types: scalar (single value), row (single row), table (multiple rows/columns)
FROM subquery creates 'derived table' - must have alias
topics.description: Introduction to Subqueries

topics.name: Subqueries
learningTip: Different subquery types for different purposes
Scalar: returns single value, can use with =, >, <
Column: returns single column, use with IN, ANY, ALL
Table: returns multiple columns, use as derived table in FROM
mustNotMiss: Scalar: WHERE qty = (SELECT MAX(qty) FROM products) - single value
Column: WHERE id IN (SELECT product_id FROM order_items) - list of values
Table/Derived: FROM (SELECT ...) AS derived_table - must have alias
Subquery in SELECT: SELECT name, (SELECT COUNT(*) FROM orders WHERE ...) AS order_count
topics.description: Nested queries with Subqueries

topics.name: The IN Operator with Subqueries
learningTip: IN with subquery checks if value exists in result set
Alternative to JOIN in some cases
NOT IN has NULL trap - prefer NOT EXISTS
Optimizer often converts to JOIN internally
mustNotMiss: WHERE customer_id IN (SELECT customer_id FROM orders)
Customers who have placed orders
NOT IN WARNING: if subquery returns NULL, entire NOT IN returns false!
Prefer NOT EXISTS for 'not in' with possible NULLs
topics.description: Using The IN Operator with Subqueries for conditional filtering

topics.name: Subqueries vs Joins
learningTip: Same result often achievable with subquery OR join
JOINs often more efficient but not always
Subqueries can be more readable for some patterns
Optimizer may rewrite one to the other
mustNotMiss: Subquery: SELECT * FROM orders WHERE customer_id IN (SELECT id FROM customers WHERE state = 'CA')
JOIN: SELECT o.* FROM orders o JOIN customers c ON o.customer_id = c.id WHERE c.state = 'CA'
JOIN better for: need data from both tables, multiple matches
Subquery better for: EXISTS/NOT EXISTS, clearer logic
topics.description: Combine data from multiple tables using Subqueries vs Joins

topics.name: The ALL Keyword
learningTip: ALL compares value against ALL results from subquery
> ALL means greater than the maximum
< ALL means less than the minimum
Empty result from subquery: ALL is TRUE
mustNotMiss: WHERE price > ALL (SELECT price FROM products WHERE category = 'low') - more than any low-category product
> ALL is equivalent to > (SELECT MAX(...))
< ALL is equivalent to < (SELECT MIN(...))
If subquery returns empty, condition is TRUE (vacuous truth)
topics.description: Master The ALL Keyword for effective SQL queries

topics.name: The ANY Keyword
learningTip: ANY (or SOME) matches if condition holds for at least one subquery value
> ANY means greater than the minimum
= ANY is equivalent to IN
Matches if at least one comparison is true
mustNotMiss: WHERE price > ANY (SELECT price FROM products WHERE category = 'high') - more than at least one
> ANY is equivalent to > (SELECT MIN(...))
= ANY is exactly the same as IN
If subquery returns empty, condition is FALSE
topics.description: Master The ANY Keyword for effective SQL queries

topics.name: Correlated Subqueries
learningTip: Subquery references outer query - runs ONCE per outer row
More powerful but potentially slower
Use when inner query depends on outer query values
Often can be rewritten as JOIN for better performance
mustNotMiss: SELECT * FROM employees e WHERE salary > (SELECT AVG(salary) FROM employees WHERE department_id = e.department_id)
Notice: inner query uses e.department_id from outer query
Runs N times (once per outer row) - can be slow
EXISTS is often used with correlated subqueries
topics.description: Nested queries with Correlated Subqueries

topics.name: The EXISTS Operator
learningTip: EXISTS checks if subquery returns ANY rows
Returns TRUE/FALSE, doesn't care about actual values
Often more efficient than IN for correlated checks
NOT EXISTS is the clean pattern for 'not in'
mustNotMiss: SELECT * FROM customers c WHERE EXISTS (SELECT 1 FROM orders o WHERE o.customer_id = c.id)
SELECT 1 is convention - value doesn't matter, only existence
NOT EXISTS safely handles NULLs (unlike NOT IN)
Stops at first match - often faster than IN
topics.description: Using The EXISTS Operator for conditional filtering

topics.name: Subqueries in the SELECT Clause
learningTip: Subquery in SELECT calculates derived columns: SELECT name, (SELECT COUNT(*) FROM orders WHERE user_id = users.id) AS order_count.
mustNotMiss: Each row runs the subquery - can be slow. Alternative: LEFT JOIN with COUNT. SELECT name, COUNT(o.id) FROM users LEFT JOIN orders o ON ... GROUP BY users.id. Test both approaches with real data volumes.
topics.description: Master the Subqueries in the SELECT Clause for data retrieval

topics.name: Subqueries in the FROM Clause
learningTip: Subquery in FROM creates a derived table (temporary table-like): SELECT * FROM (SELECT ... ) AS subquery.
mustNotMiss: Derived table must have alias. Useful for: pre-aggregating data, breaking complex queries into steps, applying filters to aggregated results. MySQL materializes derived tables - can be memory-intensive for large results.
topics.description: Nested queries with Subqueries in the FROM Clause

topics.name: Numeric Functions
learningTip: Built-in functions for mathematical operations
ROUND, CEILING, FLOOR for rounding
ABS, MOD, POWER for common math
Useful in calculations and data formatting
mustNotMiss: ROUND(5.567, 2) = 5.57. ROUND(5.567) = 6 (default 0 decimals)
CEILING(5.1) = 6, FLOOR(5.9) = 5 (always up/down)
TRUNCATE(5.567, 2) = 5.56 (cuts, doesn't round)
MOD(7, 3) = 1 or 7 % 3 = 1 (modulo/remainder)
topics.description: SQL functions for Numeric Functions

topics.name: String Functions
learningTip: String manipulation is essential for data cleaning
CONCAT, SUBSTRING, LENGTH, TRIM, UPPER, LOWER
Pattern matching with LOCATE, REPLACE
MySQL is 1-indexed for string positions!
mustNotMiss: CONCAT('Hello', ' ', 'World') = 'Hello World'
SUBSTRING(str, start, length) - 1-indexed! SUBSTRING('Hello', 2, 3) = 'ell'
LENGTH('Hello') = 5, UPPER('hello') = 'HELLO'
TRIM('  hello  ') = 'hello', LTRIM/RTRIM for left/right only
topics.description: SQL functions for String Functions

topics.name: Date Functions in MySQL
learningTip: Date manipulation is critical for reporting
NOW(), CURDATE(), CURTIME() for current date/time
EXTRACT parts: YEAR(), MONTH(), DAY()
Date arithmetic with DATE_ADD, DATE_SUB
mustNotMiss: DATE_ADD('2024-01-15', INTERVAL 1 MONTH) = '2024-02-15'
topics.description: SQL functions for Date Functions in MySQL

topics.name: Formatting Dates and Times
learningTip: DATE_FORMAT converts dates to custom string format
Format specifiers: %Y (4-digit year), %m (month), %d (day)
Essential for user-facing output
STR_TO_DATE does the reverse (string to date)
mustNotMiss: DATE_FORMAT(NOW(), '%M %d, %Y') = 'January 15, 2024'
STR_TO_DATE('15-01-2024', '%d-%m-%Y') converts string to date
topics.description: Master Formatting Dates and Times for effective SQL queries

topics.name: Calculating Dates and Times
learningTip: DATE_ADD, DATE_SUB, DATEDIFF, TIMESTAMPDIFF for date arithmetic. Essential for age calculations, expiration checks, reporting periods.
mustNotMiss: TIMESTAMPDIFF(YEAR, birth_date, CURDATE()) gives age in years. DATEDIFF gives days only. For business days, you need custom logic. Common pattern: Find records from last 30 days: WHERE created_at >= DATE_SUB(CURDATE(), INTERVAL 30 DAY).
topics.description: Master Calculating Dates and Times for effective SQL queries

topics.name: The IFNULL and COALESCE Functions

practiceQuestions.name: Replace Employee ID With The Unique Identifier

learningTip: Handle NULL values by providing defaults
IFNULL(expr, default) - MySQL specific, two arguments
COALESCE(expr1, expr2, ...) - SQL standard, multiple arguments
COALESCE returns first non-NULL value
mustNotMiss: IFNULL(phone, 'N/A') - if phone is NULL, show 'N/A'
COALESCE(phone, mobile, email, 'No contact') - first non-null
COALESCE is more portable (works in all databases)
Use for calculations: IFNULL(discount, 0) to treat NULL as zero
topics.description: SQL functions for The IFNULL and COALESCE Functions

topics.name: The IF Function
learningTip: IF() provides conditional logic in SELECT
IF(condition, true_value, false_value)
CASE provides more complex conditionals
Useful for data transformation in output
mustNotMiss: IF(quantity > 10, 'In Stock', 'Low Stock') AS status
CASE WHEN qty > 10 THEN 'High' WHEN qty > 5 THEN 'Medium' ELSE 'Low' END
CASE is more readable for multiple conditions
Both work in SELECT, ORDER BY, and WHERE
topics.description: SQL functions for The IF Function

topics.name: The CASE Operator
learningTip: CASE provides multi-way branching. Two forms: simple (CASE expr WHEN...) and searched (CASE WHEN condition...).
mustNotMiss: Searched CASE: CASE WHEN score >= 90 THEN 'A' WHEN score >= 80 THEN 'B' ELSE 'F' END. Simple CASE: CASE status WHEN 1 THEN 'Active' WHEN 0 THEN 'Inactive' END. CASE works in SELECT, ORDER BY, WHERE, and aggregate functions. Essential for pivot tables and conditional aggregation.
topics.description: Using The CASE Operator for conditional filtering

topics.name: Creating Views
learningTip: CREATE VIEW name AS SELECT... Views are saved queries that act like virtual tables. They don't store data.
mustNotMiss: Views simplify complex queries, provide security (expose only certain columns), and create abstraction layers. CREATE VIEW active_customers AS SELECT * FROM customers WHERE status = 'active'. Then: SELECT * FROM active_customers. Changes to underlying tables reflect in view.
topics.description: Virtual tables with Creating Views

topics.name: Altering or Dropping Views
learningTip: CREATE OR REPLACE VIEW rewrites existing view. DROP VIEW removes it. ALTER VIEW also works but less common.
mustNotMiss: CREATE OR REPLACE is safer than DROP + CREATE (permissions preserved). View definitions stored in information_schema.views. List views: SHOW FULL TABLES WHERE Table_type = 'VIEW'. Document view purposes in comments.
topics.description: Virtual tables with Altering or Dropping Views

topics.name: Updatable Views
learningTip: Some views allow INSERT, UPDATE, DELETE
Requirements: single table, no aggregation, no DISTINCT
WITH CHECK OPTION prevents updates that would remove row from view
Useful for controlled data access
mustNotMiss: Simple view on single table without DISTINCT, aggregates = updatable
CREATE VIEW active_products AS SELECT * FROM products WHERE active = 1 WITH CHECK OPTION
WITH CHECK OPTION: can't update active to 0 (would remove from view)
JOINs, subqueries, GROUP BY make view non-updatable
topics.description: Virtual tables with Updatable Views

topics.name: THE WITH OPTION CHECK Clause
learningTip: WITH CHECK OPTION prevents INSERT/UPDATE that would make row invisible to the view.
mustNotMiss: CREATE VIEW expensive_products AS SELECT * FROM products WHERE price > 100 WITH CHECK OPTION. Trying to set price = 50 through this view fails. Two types: LOCAL (check this view only) and CASCADED (check all underlying views). Cascaded is default.
topics.description: Master THE WITH OPTION CHECK Clause for effective SQL queries

topics.name: Other Benefits of Views
learningTip: Views provide: query simplification, security (limit data exposure), abstraction (hide schema complexity), backward compatibility during refactoring.
mustNotMiss: Security: View shows only non-sensitive columns, grant access to view not table. Abstraction: Complex joins become simple table-like interface. Migration: Old queries use view pointing to new schema. Performance note: Views don't cache - query runs each time.
topics.description: Virtual tables with Other Benefits of Views

topics.name: What are Stored Procedures
learningTip: Stored procedure = saved program stored in database
Contains SQL statements plus procedural logic
Benefits: code reuse, security, reduced network traffic
Drawbacks: harder to version control, less portable
mustNotMiss: DELIMITER // CREATE PROCEDURE proc_name() BEGIN ... END // DELIMITER ;
CALL proc_name() to execute
DROP PROCEDURE proc_name to delete
SHOW PROCEDURE STATUS to list procedures
topics.description: Stored logic with What are Stored Procedures

topics.name: Creating a Stored Procedure
learningTip: CREATE PROCEDURE name(params) BEGIN ... END. Use DELIMITER to change statement terminator during creation.
mustNotMiss: DELIMITER $$ CREATE PROCEDURE GetCustomer(IN id INT) BEGIN SELECT * FROM customers WHERE customer_id = id; END $$ DELIMITER ; Call with: CALL GetCustomer(123). IN parameters are input, OUT are return values, INOUT are both.
topics.description: Stored logic with Creating a Stored Procedure

topics.name: Creating Procedures Using MySQLWorkbench
learningTip: MySQL Workbench provides GUI for creating procedures. Easier for beginners but learn command-line for scripting.
mustNotMiss: Workbench shows procedure list under Stored Procedures. Right-click to create, alter, or drop. For team environments, store procedure definitions in version control as SQL files, not just in database.
topics.description: Stored logic with Creating Procedures Using MySQLWorkbench

topics.name: Dropping Stored Procedures
learningTip: DROP PROCEDURE IF EXISTS name. Always use IF EXISTS to avoid errors when procedure doesn't exist.
mustNotMiss: Common pattern for updates: DROP PROCEDURE IF EXISTS MyProc; CREATE PROCEDURE MyProc... This is effectively 'create or replace'. For checking existence before conditional logic: SELECT COUNT(*) FROM information_schema.routines WHERE routine_name = 'MyProc'.
topics.description: Stored logic with Dropping Stored Procedures

topics.name: Parameters
learningTip: Parameters pass data into and out of procedures
IN: input only (default), OUT: output only, INOUT: both
IN parameters cannot be modified inside procedure
OUT/INOUT must be user variables when calling
mustNotMiss: CREATE PROCEDURE get_orders(IN customer_id INT, OUT order_count INT)
CALL get_orders(5, @count); SELECT @count;
@variable is user-defined variable
IN parameters can have default: IN limit INT DEFAULT 10
topics.description: Master Parameters for effective SQL queries

topics.name: Parameters with Default Value
learningTip: MySQL doesn't support default parameter values directly. Workaround: use NULL as default and IFNULL inside.
mustNotMiss: Pattern: CREATE PROCEDURE Search(IN term VARCHAR(50)) BEGIN SET term = IFNULL(term, '%'); SELECT * FROM products WHERE name LIKE term; END. If NULL passed, searches all. Document expected parameters clearly since defaults aren't obvious.
topics.description: Master Parameters with Default Value for effective SQL queries

topics.name: Parameter Validation
learningTip: Validate parameters early. Use IF statements and SIGNAL to raise errors for invalid input.
mustNotMiss: SIGNAL SQLSTATE '45000' SET MESSAGE_TEXT = 'Invalid parameter'; raises custom error. Pattern: IF param IS NULL OR param < 0 THEN SIGNAL... END IF. Validate before processing to fail fast with clear errors.
topics.description: Master Parameter Validation for effective SQL queries

topics.name: Output Parameters
learningTip: OUT parameters return multiple values. Set values with SELECT INTO or SET statements.
mustNotMiss: Pattern: CREATE PROCEDURE GetStats(OUT minVal DECIMAL, OUT maxVal DECIMAL, OUT avgVal DECIMAL) BEGIN SELECT MIN(price), MAX(price), AVG(price) INTO minVal, maxVal, avgVal FROM products; END. CALL GetStats(@min, @max, @avg); returns three values.
topics.description: Master Output Parameters for effective SQL queries

topics.name: Variables
learningTip: Local variables declared with DECLARE inside procedure
Must declare before use, at start of BEGIN block
SET assigns values, SELECT INTO also works
Scope is within the BEGIN...END block
mustNotMiss: DECLARE total DECIMAL(10,2) DEFAULT 0;
SET total = 100; or SELECT SUM(price) INTO total FROM ...
Variables are local to procedure - not visible outside
@user_variables are session-scoped (visible everywhere in session)
topics.description: Master Variables for effective SQL queries

topics.name: Functions
learningTip: CREATE FUNCTION returns a single value. Must specify RETURNS type and DETERMINISTIC/NOT DETERMINISTIC.
mustNotMiss: Functions can be used in SELECT, WHERE, etc. CREATE FUNCTION FormatPhone(phone VARCHAR
RETURNS VARCHAR
DETERMINISTIC RETURN CONCAT('(', LEFT(phone,
, ') ', ...); Deterministic means same input always gives same output - enables optimization.
topics.description: SQL functions for Functions

topics.name: Other Conventions
learningTip: Naming: prefix procedures with sp_ or proc_, functions with fn_. Comment liberally. Follow consistent formatting.
mustNotMiss: Error handling: Use DECLARE CONTINUE/EXIT HANDLER for exception handling. Logging: Insert into log tables for debugging. Testing: Create test procedures that call and verify main procedures. Keep procedures focused - one task each.
topics.description: Master Other Conventions for effective SQL queries

topics.name: Triggers
learningTip: Triggers execute automatically before/after INSERT, UPDATE, DELETE. Used for auditing, validation, maintaining derived data.
mustNotMiss: CREATE TRIGGER name BEFORE INSERT ON table FOR EACH ROW BEGIN ... END. Access values with NEW (for INSERT/UPDATE new values) and OLD (for UPDATE/DELETE old values). Triggers are powerful but hidden - document them well. Can cause cascading effects.
topics.description: Stored logic with Triggers

topics.name: Viewing Triggers
learningTip: SHOW TRIGGERS shows active triggers. Check information_schema.triggers for details.
mustNotMiss: SHOW TRIGGERS FROM database_name. Triggers don't show in SHOW CREATE TABLE. Debug by temporarily disabling: Set trigger body to empty or drop and recreate. For complex trigger logic, consider moving to application code for visibility.
topics.description: Virtual tables with Viewing Triggers

topics.name: Dropping Triggers
learningTip: DROP TRIGGER IF EXISTS name. Triggers tied to tables - dropping table drops its triggers.
mustNotMiss: Cannot ALTER TRIGGER - must drop and recreate. Store trigger definitions in SQL files for version control and recovery. During migration, may need to disable/re-enable triggers to avoid side effects during bulk operations.
topics.description: Stored logic with Dropping Triggers

topics.name: Using Triggers for Auditing
learningTip: Common pattern: Log changes to audit table. Capture who, when, what changed.
mustNotMiss: Audit table: timestamp, table_name, operation (INSERT/UPDATE/DELETE), old_values (JSON), new_values (JSON), user. In trigger: INSERT INTO audit_log VALUES (NOW(), 'orders', 'UPDATE', JSON_OBJECT('status', OLD.status), JSON_OBJECT('status', NEW.status), USER()).
topics.description: Stored logic with Using Triggers for Auditing

topics.name: Events
learningTip: Events are scheduled tasks. CREATE EVENT runs SQL on schedule - hourly, daily, or custom cron-like timing.
mustNotMiss: CREATE EVENT daily_cleanup ON SCHEDULE EVERY 1 DAY DO DELETE FROM logs WHERE created_at < DATE_SUB(NOW(), INTERVAL 30 DAY); Events need event_scheduler = ON in config. Use for: cleanup, summarization, periodic updates, data archiving.
topics.description: Master Events for effective SQL queries

topics.name: Viewing, Dropping and Altering Events
learningTip: SHOW EVENTS lists events. ALTER EVENT modifies schedule or enables/disables. DROP EVENT removes.
mustNotMiss: ALTER EVENT name DISABLE; temporarily stops execution. ALTER EVENT name ON SCHEDULE EVERY 1 HOUR; changes frequency. Events run with definer's privileges. For debugging, check event_scheduler status and MySQL error log.
topics.description: Virtual tables with Viewing, Dropping and Altering Events

topics.name: Transactions
learningTip: Transaction = group of operations treated as single unit
All succeed together or all fail together
ACID: Atomicity, Consistency, Isolation, Durability
Essential for data integrity
mustNotMiss: START TRANSACTION; ... COMMIT; (save changes)
START TRANSACTION; ... ROLLBACK; (undo changes)
Auto-commit is ON by default - each statement is transaction
Classic example: transfer money between accounts
topics.description: Data integrity with Transactions

topics.name: Creating Transactions
learningTip: START TRANSACTION; operations; COMMIT; or ROLLBACK;. Autocommit is default in MySQL - each statement is its own transaction.
mustNotMiss: SET autocommit = 0; disables auto-commit for session. Explicit transactions: START TRANSACTION; UPDATE...; UPDATE...; COMMIT; If error occurs, ROLLBACK undoes all changes since START TRANSACTION. Always handle errors to avoid hanging transactions.
topics.description: Data integrity with Creating Transactions

topics.name: Concurrency and Locking
learningTip: Locks prevent conflicting concurrent access. Row locks, table locks. FOR UPDATE locks selected rows until transaction ends.
mustNotMiss: SELECT * FROM accounts WHERE id = 1 FOR UPDATE; locks that row. Other transactions wait (block) until lock released. Excessive locking hurts performance. Lock only what you need, for shortest time. InnoDB uses row-level locking; MyISAM uses table-level.
topics.description: Master Concurrency and Locking for effective SQL queries

topics.name: Concurrency Problems
learningTip: Problems: Lost updates (both write, one overwrites), dirty reads (read uncommitted), non-repeatable reads (same query, different results), phantom reads (new rows appear).
mustNotMiss: Lost update: Two users edit same record, last save wins. Solution: Check version/timestamp before update. Dirty read: Reading data that might be rolled back. Non-repeatable: Same SELECT returns different data. Phantom: New rows match WHERE clause. Isolation levels address these.
topics.description: Master Concurrency Problems for effective SQL queries

topics.name: Transaction Isolation Levels
learningTip: Isolation levels control how transactions see each other
Lower isolation = better performance, more concurrency issues
Higher isolation = safer but slower
Choose based on application requirements
mustNotMiss: READ UNCOMMITTED: can see uncommitted changes (dirty reads)
READ COMMITTED: only see committed data (PostgreSQL/Oracle default)
REPEATABLE READ: same data throughout transaction (MySQL default)
SERIALIZABLE: transactions appear sequential (highest isolation, slowest)
topics.description: Data integrity with Transaction Isolation Levels

topics.name: READ UNCOMMITTED Isolation Level
learningTip: Lowest isolation. Can read uncommitted changes from other transactions. Dirty reads possible.
mustNotMiss: Use case: Quick estimates where exact data isn't critical (dashboard counts). Do NOT use for financial or critical data. SET TRANSACTION ISOLATION LEVEL READ UNCOMMITTED; or SELECT... WITH (NOLOCK) in SQL Server.
topics.description: Master READ UNCOMMITTED Isolation Level for effective SQL queries

topics.name: READ COMMITTED Isolation Level
learningTip: Each read sees only committed data at that moment. No dirty reads, but non-repeatable reads possible.
mustNotMiss: Default in PostgreSQL, Oracle. Two SELECTs in same transaction might return different results if data committed between them. Good balance for most applications. Slightly less overhead than REPEATABLE READ.
topics.description: Master READ COMMITTED Isolation Level for effective SQL queries

topics.name: REPEATABLE READ Isolation Level
learningTip: Same SELECT always returns same results within transaction. Locks read rows. MySQL default for InnoDB.
mustNotMiss: Phantom reads still possible: new rows matching criteria can appear. MySQL's implementation actually prevents most phantoms too (gap locking). Good for transactions that need consistent view of data they've read.
topics.description: Master REPEATABLE READ Isolation Level for effective SQL queries

topics.name: SERIALIZABLE Isolation Level
learningTip: Highest isolation. Transactions execute as if serial (one after another). System may reject transactions to prevent conflicts.
mustNotMiss: Maximum correctness, minimum concurrency. Transactions may fail with 'deadlock' or 'lock timeout'. Use for: financial transactions, inventory updates, anything requiring absolute consistency. Application must handle retry logic.
topics.description: Master SERIALIZABLE Isolation Level for effective SQL queries

topics.name: Deadlocks
learningTip: Deadlock: Two transactions each waiting for lock held by the other. Neither can proceed.
mustNotMiss: MySQL detects deadlocks and kills one transaction (victim). Application should catch error and retry. Prevent by: accessing tables in same order, locking all needed rows upfront, keeping transactions short. SHOW ENGINE INNODB STATUS shows recent deadlocks.
topics.description: Master Deadlocks for effective SQL queries

topics.name: Introduction to Data Types
learningTip: Choosing right data type affects storage size, performance, and data integrity. Type too small truncates data; too large wastes space.
mustNotMiss: Categories: String, Numeric, Date/Time, JSON, Blob. Consider: size of data, required precision, query patterns. Use smallest type that fits. Changing types later requires migration. Plan schema carefully.
topics.description: Introduction to Data Types

topics.name: String Types
learningTip: CHAR(n): fixed length, padded with spaces. VARCHAR(n): variable length, uses only needed space. TEXT for large text.
mustNotMiss: CHAR is faster for fixed-length data (like country codes). VARCHAR for variable (names, emails). TEXT for long content (articles). VARCHAR max is 65535 bytes but limited by row size. For very long text, use TEXT/LONGTEXT.
topics.description: Master String Types for effective SQL queries

topics.name: Integer Types
learningTip: TINYINT (1 byte), SMALLINT
, MEDIUMINT
, INT
, BIGINT
Signed/unsigned affects range.
mustNotMiss: INT UNSIGNED: 0 to 4 billion. INT SIGNED: -2B to +2B. BIGINT for huge numbers (row IDs in big tables). Use smallest that fits: age = TINYINT UNSIGNED (0-255), order_id = INT UNSIGNED. Primary keys: start with INT, migrate to BIGINT when needed.
topics.description: Master Integer Types for effective SQL queries

topics.name: Fixed-point and Floating-point Types
learningTip: FLOAT, DOUBLE for approximate decimals. DECIMAL(p,s) for exact decimals (money!).
mustNotMiss: FLOAT/DOUBLE have rounding errors:
1 might not equal
3 exactly. DECIMAL(10,
stores exactly what you put in - USE FOR MONEY. DECIMAL is slower than FLOAT/DOUBLE but accuracy matters more for financial data.
topics.description: Master Fixed-point and Floating-point Types for effective SQL queries

topics.name: Boolean Types
learningTip: MySQL's BOOL/BOOLEAN is actually TINYINT(1). 0 = false, non-zero = true.
mustNotMiss: Common values: 0 and
WHERE is_active = TRUE works (TRUE =
Can use WHERE is_active (non-zero is truthy). Best practice: Use TINYINT
with 0/1 values. Some ORMs map to true/false automatically.
topics.description: Master Boolean Types for effective SQL queries

topics.name: Enum and Set Types
learningTip: ENUM('val1','val2') stores one of predefined values. SET('a','b','c') stores multiple values from list.
mustNotMiss: ENUM is compact (1-2 bytes) and self-documenting. BUT: Adding values requires ALTER TABLE, order matters for sorting. Alternative: Use lookup table with foreign key for flexibility. SET rarely used - consider junction table for many-to-many.
topics.description: Master Enum and Set Types for effective SQL queries

topics.name: Date and Time Types
learningTip: DATE (date only), TIME (time only), DATETIME (both), TIMESTAMP (both + auto UTC conversion), YEAR.
mustNotMiss: DATETIME: 1000-9999, no timezone conversion. TIMESTAMP: 1970-2038, converts to/from UTC based on session timezone. Use TIMESTAMP for created_at/updated_at (auto-update); DATETIME for business dates (birthday, event date). Be aware of 2038 limit for TIMESTAMP.
topics.description: Master Date and Time Types for effective SQL queries

topics.name: Blob Types
learningTip: BLOB (binary large object) stores binary data: images, files, encrypted data. TINYBLOB to LONGBLOB by size.
mustNotMiss: Generally avoid storing files in database. Better: Store in filesystem/S3, save path in database. Reasons: Database backup size, replication overhead, not cacheable by CDN. Exceptions: Small binary data, security requirements for encryption, transactional integrity with related data.
topics.description: Master Blob Types for effective SQL queries

topics.name: JSON Type
learningTip: JSON type validates JSON on insert. Supports JSON functions: JSON_EXTRACT, JSON_SET, ->> operator for extraction.
mustNotMiss: SELECT data->>'$.name' extracts nested JSON. JSON_EXTRACT(data, '$.items[0].id'). Indexing: Create generated column from JSON path, index that column. Use for: flexible schemas, nested data, when NoSQL-like patterns fit. Don't use for data you query frequently - extract to columns.
topics.description: Master JSON Type for effective SQL queries

topics.name: Introduction to Database Design
learningTip: Good database design balances normalization (reduce redundancy) with query performance (sometimes denormalize).
mustNotMiss: Design process: Requirements → Conceptual model (entities, relationships) → Logical model (tables, constraints) → Physical model (types, indexes). Start normalized, denormalize where performance requires. Document decisions - future you will thank past you.
topics.description: Introduction to Database Design

topics.name: Data Modelling
learningTip: Modeling identifies entities (things), attributes (properties), and relationships (connections). Start with business requirements.
mustNotMiss: Entity examples: Customer, Order, Product. Attributes: Customer.name, Order.date, Product.price. Relationships: Customer places Order (1:many), Order contains Products (many:many). Cardinality (1:1, 1:N, N:M) and optionality (required vs optional) define relationship rules.
topics.description: Master Data Modelling for effective SQL queries

topics.name: Conceptual Models
learningTip: High-level view: entities, relationships, no implementation details. Use ER diagrams. Focus on WHAT, not HOW.
mustNotMiss: Entity-Relationship diagram shows boxes (entities), lines (relationships), cardinality. At this stage: 'Customer', 'Order', 'Product' - no mention of foreign keys, data types, or tables. Validate with stakeholders before implementing.
topics.description: Master Conceptual Models for effective SQL queries

topics.name: Logical Models
learningTip: Tables, columns, relationships, constraints - independent of specific database. Add primary keys, foreign keys.
mustNotMiss: Transform conceptual to logical: Entities → tables, attributes → columns, relationships → foreign keys. Many-to-many → junction table. Add data types (but generic: 'string', 'integer', not MySQL-specific). Normalize to 3NF typically.
topics.description: Master Logical Models for effective SQL queries

topics.name: Physical Models
learningTip: Database-specific implementation: exact data types, indexes, storage engines, partitioning.
mustNotMiss: VARCHAR(255), INT UNSIGNED, ENGINE=InnoDB. Add indexes based on query patterns. Consider partitioning for large tables. Clustering for frequently joined tables. Physical model is what you actually CREATE in MySQL.
topics.description: Master Physical Models for effective SQL queries

topics.name: Primary Keys
learningTip: Primary key uniquely identifies each row
Must be NOT NULL and UNIQUE
Usually auto-increment integer or UUID
Every table should have one
mustNotMiss: Natural key (business data like email) vs Surrogate key (auto-generated)
Surrogate recommended: business data can change
AUTO_INCREMENT for single server, UUID for distributed
PRIMARY KEY creates clustered index in InnoDB
topics.description: Master Primary Keys for effective SQL queries

topics.name: Foreign Keys
learningTip: Foreign key creates relationship between tables
References primary key of another table
Enforces referential integrity at database level
Prevents orphaned records
mustNotMiss: FOREIGN KEY (customer_id) REFERENCES customers(id)
Cannot insert foreign key value that doesn't exist in parent
ON DELETE CASCADE: auto-delete children when parent deleted
ON DELETE SET NULL: set foreign key to NULL when parent deleted
topics.description: Master Foreign Keys for effective SQL queries

topics.name: Foreign Key Constraints
learningTip: ON DELETE/UPDATE actions: RESTRICT (block), CASCADE (propagate), SET NULL, NO ACTION (similar to RESTRICT).
mustNotMiss: CASCADE: Delete parent, children auto-deleted. Powerful but dangerous. SET NULL: Child keeps row but foreign key becomes NULL. RESTRICT: Safest - must delete children first. Choose based on business rules. Common: orders CASCADE to order_items, but customers RESTRICT from orders.
topics.description: Master Foreign Key Constraints for effective SQL queries

topics.name: Normalization
learningTip: Normalization reduces redundancy and prevents update anomalies
Normal forms: 1NF, 2NF, 3NF are most practical
Trade-off: normalized = more JOINs, denormalized = faster reads
Usually aim for 3NF, denormalize strategically
mustNotMiss: 1NF: atomic values, no repeating groups (each cell has single value)
2NF: 1NF + no partial dependencies (all non-key columns depend on full key)
3NF: 2NF + no transitive dependencies (non-key columns don't depend on each other)
Denormalize for: read-heavy workloads, reporting, caching
topics.description: Database design using Normalization

topics.name: 1NF- First Normal Form
learningTip: 1NF: Each column contains atomic values, each row is unique (has primary key).
mustNotMiss: Violations: Comma-separated values in a column, repeating groups (phone1, phone2, phone3). Fix: Split into separate table with proper relationships. Example: products table with 'colors: red,blue' → product_colors junction table.
topics.description: Master 1NF- First Normal Form for effective SQL queries

topics.name: Link Tables
learningTip: Junction/bridge tables implement many-to-many relationships. Contains foreign keys to both related tables.
mustNotMiss: Example: students ↔ courses needs student_courses(student_id, course_id). Composite primary key or separate id. Can add attributes: enrollment_date, grade. Always create junction tables for N:M relationships.
topics.description: Master Link Tables for effective SQL queries

topics.name: 2NF- Second Normal Form
learningTip: 2NF: 1NF + every non-key attribute depends on the whole primary key (not just part of a composite key).
mustNotMiss: Applies to tables with composite primary keys. Example: order_items(order_id, product_id, product_name). Product_name depends only on product_id, not full key. Fix: Move product_name to products table.
topics.description: Master 2NF- Second Normal Form for effective SQL queries

topics.name: 3NF- Third Normal Form
learningTip: 3NF: 2NF + no transitive dependencies (non-key column shouldn't depend on another non-key column).
mustNotMiss: Example: employees(id, department_id, department_name). Department_name depends on department_id, not directly on employee id. Fix: Separate departments table with only department_id in employees. Most databases should be in 3NF.
topics.description: Master 3NF- Third Normal Form for effective SQL queries

topics.name: My Pragmatic Advice
learningTip: Normalize by default, denormalize for specific performance needs. Don't over-engineer. Start simple, evolve as needed.
mustNotMiss: Real-world: 3NF is usually enough. Denormalize for: reporting tables, frequently joined lookup data, caching expensive calculations. Document denormalization reasons. Profile before optimizing - measure actual performance issues.
topics.description: Master My Pragmatic Advice for effective SQL queries

topics.name: Don't Model the Universe
learningTip: Model only what you need now. Avoid speculative complexity. YAGNI (You Aren't Gonna Need It) applies to schema too.
mustNotMiss: Don't create 10 address tables 'just in case' when you only need one. Schema migrations exist. Start minimal, add as requirements emerge. Over-engineering wastes development time and adds runtime complexity.
topics.description: Master Don't Model the Universe for effective SQL queries

topics.name: Forward Engineering a Model
learningTip: Generate SQL DDL from your data model. Takes logical/physical model and creates actual database.
mustNotMiss: MySQL Workbench: Database → Forward Engineer. Generates CREATE TABLE statements with all constraints. Review generated SQL before running. Useful for: deploying to new environments, creating documentation, version controlling schema.
topics.description: Master Forward Engineering a Model for effective SQL queries

topics.name: Synchronizing a Model with a Database
learningTip: Keep model diagram in sync with actual database. Changes made directly to database should reflect in model.
mustNotMiss: MySQL Workbench: Database → Synchronize Model. Compares model to live database, shows differences, generates ALTER statements. Essential for maintaining documentation. Run after any direct SQL changes to database.
topics.description: Master Synchronizing a Model with a Database for effective SQL queries

topics.name: Reverse Engineering a Database
learningTip: Generate model diagram from existing database. Understand legacy systems or document undocumented databases.
mustNotMiss: MySQL Workbench: Database → Reverse Engineer. Connects to database, reads schema, creates ER diagram. Relationships are inferred from foreign keys. May need manual adjustment for implicit relationships. Great for onboarding to new projects.
topics.description: Master Reverse Engineering a Database for effective SQL queries

topics.name: Project- Flight Booking System
learningTip: Real-world modeling exercise. Consider: passengers, flights, bookings, seats, airports, airlines, payments.
mustNotMiss: Practice identifying entities, relationships, cardinalities. Many-to-many: passengers ↔ flights (via bookings). One-to-many: flights → seats. Consider: flight schedule vs instances, seat classes, cancellations, check-ins.
topics.description: Master Project- Flight Booking System for effective SQL queries

topics.name: Solution- Conceptual Model
learningTip: High-level entities: Passenger, Flight, Booking, Airport, Airline. Focus on business concepts, not tables.
mustNotMiss: Relationships: Passenger makes Booking for Flight. Flight departs from/arrives at Airport. Flight operated by Airline. Don't worry about implementation - just capture the business domain clearly.
topics.description: Master Solution- Conceptual Model for effective SQL queries

topics.name: Solution- Logical Model
learningTip: Transform to tables: passengers, flights, bookings, airports, airlines. Add keys and relationships.
mustNotMiss: Booking is junction between Passenger and Flight with attributes (seat, class, price). Foreign keys enforce relationships. Consider: timestamps for audit, status fields for workflow, constraints for business rules.
topics.description: Master Solution- Logical Model for effective SQL queries

topics.name: Project - Video Rental Application
learningTip: Classic case study. Entities: Customer, Movie, Rental, Category, Actor, Inventory.
mustNotMiss: Many-to-many: Movies ↔ Actors, Movies ↔ Categories. One-to-many: Customer → Rentals. Inventory layer: physical copies that can be rented vs movie titles. Due dates, late fees, return status add complexity.
topics.description: Master Project - Video Rental Application for effective SQL queries

topics.name: Solution- Conceptual Model
learningTip: Focus on: What movies exist? Who are customers? What rentals occurred? What categories exist?
mustNotMiss: Customer rents Movie (via Rental). Movie has Categories. Movie features Actors. Don't think tables yet - understand the domain. Draw ER diagram with entities as rectangles, relationships as diamonds.
topics.description: Master Solution- Conceptual Model for effective SQL queries

topics.name: Solution- Logical Model
learningTip: Tables: customers, movies, rentals, categories, actors, movie_actors (junction), movie_categories (junction), inventory.
mustNotMiss: Inventory table separates 'movie title' from 'physical copy'. Multiple copies per movie. Rental links customer to specific inventory item, not just movie. This models real-world constraints.
topics.description: Master Solution- Logical Model for effective SQL queries

topics.name: Creating and Dropping Databases
learningTip: CREATE DATABASE name [CHARACTER SET charset] [COLLATE collation]. DROP DATABASE removes entirely.
mustNotMiss: Always specify character set: CREATE DATABASE myapp CHARACTER SET utf8mb4 COLLATE utf8mb4_unicode_ci. utf8mb4 is full UTF-8 (including emojis). Check database exists: SELECT schema_name FROM information_schema.schemata. Use IF NOT EXISTS to avoid errors.
topics.description: Master Creating and Dropping Databases for effective SQL queries

topics.name: Creating Tables
learningTip: CREATE TABLE name (column definitions, constraints). Define structure, types, keys, defaults.
mustNotMiss: Syntax: CREATE TABLE users (id INT UNSIGNED AUTO_INCREMENT PRIMARY KEY, email VARCHAR(255) NOT NULL UNIQUE, created_at TIMESTAMP DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP). Always include: primary key, NOT NULL where appropriate, defaults, indexes.
topics.description: Master Creating Tables for effective SQL queries

topics.name: Altering Tables
learningTip: ALTER TABLE adds/removes/modifies columns and constraints. Changes live schema.
mustNotMiss: ADD COLUMN: ALTER TABLE t ADD col VARCHAR
AFTER existing_col. DROP COLUMN: ALTER TABLE t DROP COLUMN col. MODIFY COLUMN: ALTER TABLE t MODIFY col VARCHAR
Large tables: ALTER can lock table - use pt-online-schema-change for production.
topics.description: Master Altering Tables for effective SQL queries

topics.name: Creating Relationships
learningTip: Add foreign keys to establish relationships. Reference primary key of related table.
mustNotMiss: ALTER TABLE orders ADD CONSTRAINT fk_customer FOREIGN KEY (customer_id) REFERENCES customers(id) ON DELETE RESTRICT ON UPDATE CASCADE. Name constraints descriptively. Foreign keys require compatible types (both INT UNSIGNED, etc.).
topics.description: Master Creating Relationships for effective SQL queries

topics.name: Altering Primary and Foreign Key Constraints
learningTip: DROP CONSTRAINT removes constraints. For primary key: ALTER TABLE t DROP PRIMARY KEY. For foreign key: use constraint name.
mustNotMiss: Find constraint names: SHOW CREATE TABLE t. Then: ALTER TABLE t DROP FOREIGN KEY fk_name. Or: ALTER TABLE t DROP INDEX idx_name. Adding: ALTER TABLE t ADD PRIMARY KEY (id); ALTER TABLE t ADD CONSTRAINT fk_name FOREIGN KEY...
topics.description: Master Altering Primary and Foreign Key Constraints for effective SQL queries

topics.name: Character Sets and Collations
learningTip: Character set defines what characters can be stored. Collation defines sorting/comparison rules.
mustNotMiss: utf8mb4: Full UTF-8 (recommended). utf8: MySQL's limited version (3-byte, no emojis). Collation: utf8mb4_unicode_ci (case-insensitive, accent-insensitive), utf8mb4_bin (binary, case-sensitive). Set at server, database, table, or column level.
topics.description: Master Character Sets and Collations for effective SQL queries

topics.name: Storage Engines
learningTip: Engine determines how data is stored and managed. InnoDB (default, full-featured) vs MyISAM (legacy, simpler).
mustNotMiss: InnoDB: Transactions, foreign keys, row-level locking, crash recovery. Use InnoDB. MyISAM: No transactions, table-level locking, full-text search (but InnoDB has this now). Other engines: Memory, Archive for special cases.
topics.description: Master Storage Engines for effective SQL queries

topics.name: Introduction to Indexing
learningTip: Index = data structure that speeds up queries
Like book index: find data without scanning every page
Trade-off: faster reads, slower writes (index must be updated)
Choose indexes based on actual query patterns
mustNotMiss: CREATE INDEX idx_name ON table(column)
Primary key automatically creates index (clustered in InnoDB)
Index columns used in: WHERE, JOIN, ORDER BY
EXPLAIN shows if index is being used
topics.description: Introduction to Indexing

topics.name: Indexes
learningTip: Types: B-tree (default, general purpose), Hash (equality only), Full-text (text search), Spatial (GIS).
mustNotMiss: B-tree: Works for =, <, >, <=, >=, BETWEEN, LIKE 'prefix%'. Range scans efficient. Hash: Only for exact equality, very fast but limited. MySQL InnoDB uses B+ tree variant. Understanding index structures helps optimize.
topics.description: Optimize query performance using Indexes

topics.name: Creating Indexes
learningTip: CREATE INDEX name ON table(column). Can be UNIQUE. Multi-column: CREATE INDEX name ON table(col1, col2).
mustNotMiss: Primary key automatically creates clustered index. CREATE INDEX idx_email ON users(email); CREATE UNIQUE INDEX idx_unique_email ON users(email); Naming convention: idx_tablename_columns or ix_columns.
topics.description: Optimize query performance using Creating Indexes

topics.name: Viewing Indexes
learningTip: SHOW INDEX FROM table. EXPLAIN shows how queries use indexes. information_schema.statistics has details.
mustNotMiss: SHOW INDEX shows: key_name, column_name, cardinality (distinct values), null allowed. High cardinality = better selectivity. EXPLAIN SELECT... shows 'key' used, 'rows' scanned. Compare rows vs total table rows.
topics.description: Optimize query performance using Viewing Indexes

topics.name: Prefix Indexes
learningTip: Index on part of string column: CREATE INDEX idx_name ON table(column(10)). Uses first 10 characters.
mustNotMiss: Useful for long VARCHAR columns. Reduces index size while maintaining selectivity. Choose prefix length by analyzing: SELECT COUNT(DISTINCT LEFT(column, 10)) / COUNT(*) for different lengths. Goal: high selectivity with small prefix.
topics.description: Optimize query performance using Prefix Indexes

topics.name: Full-text Indexes
learningTip: For text search: CREATE FULLTEXT INDEX ON table(column). Enables MATCH...AGAINST queries.
mustNotMiss: MATCH(column) AGAINST('search terms') returns relevance score. Boolean mode: MATCH(col) AGAINST('+required -excluded' IN BOOLEAN MODE). Better than LIKE '%term%' for large text. InnoDB supports fulltext since MySQL
topics.description: Optimize query performance using Full-text Indexes

topics.name: Composite Indexes
learningTip: Index on multiple columns together
Column ORDER matters for query matching
Leftmost prefix rule: index (a,b,c) works for (a), (a,b), (a,b,c)
Does NOT work for (b), (c), (b,c) alone
mustNotMiss: CREATE INDEX idx ON orders(customer_id, order_date)
Works for: WHERE customer_id = 5, WHERE customer_id = 5 AND order_date > ...
Does NOT work for: WHERE order_date > ... (without customer_id)
Put equality columns before range columns in index
topics.description: Optimize query performance using Composite Indexes

topics.name: Order of Columns in Composite Indexes
learningTip: Left-to-right matching: Index on (a, b, c) can be used if query filters on a, or a+b, or a+b+c.
mustNotMiss: Example: WHERE a = 1 AND c = 3 only uses index on 'a' (skips b, can't use c). WHERE a = 1 AND b = 2 uses both. Range conditions stop further matching: WHERE a = 1 AND b > 2 AND c = 3 - only a and b used.
topics.description: Optimize query performance using Order of Columns in Composite Indexes

topics.name: When Indexes are Ignored
learningTip: Index ignored when: function on column (YEAR(date)), type conversion (string column = number), LIKE '%suffix'.
mustNotMiss: Fix: Create computed column for YEAR(date), rewrite conditions for type match, use prefix for LIKE. Expressions like (column + 1) prevent index use. Check with EXPLAIN - if 'key' shows NULL, index not used.
topics.description: Optimize query performance using When Indexes are Ignored

topics.name: Using Indexes for Sorting
learningTip: Index used for ORDER BY if columns match index order. Mixed ASC/DESC requires matching or MySQL 8.0+ index.
mustNotMiss: Index (a ASC, b DESC) helps ORDER BY a ASC, b DESC. Without matching, sort uses filesort (slower). Covering index that includes ORDER BY columns avoids table access. LIMIT with ORDER BY benefits greatly from proper index.
topics.description: Optimize query performance using Using Indexes for Sorting

topics.name: Covering Indexes
learningTip: Index that contains all columns needed for query. Query answered entirely from index, no table access.
mustNotMiss: Index on (a, b, c): Query SELECT b FROM t WHERE a = 1 uses index only. 'Using index' in EXPLAIN means covering. Add frequently SELECTed columns to index. Trade-off: larger index size vs faster queries.
topics.description: Optimize query performance using Covering Indexes

topics.name: Index Maintenance
learningTip: Indexes fragment over time. OPTIMIZE TABLE rebuilds. ANALYZE TABLE updates statistics for query optimizer.
mustNotMiss: InnoDB largely handles fragmentation automatically. ANALYZE TABLE helps optimizer choose best indexes. Run after large data changes. Scheduled maintenance during low-traffic periods. Monitor slow queries to find missing indexes.
topics.description: Optimize query performance using Index Maintenance

topics.name: Introduction to Database Security
learningTip: Defense in depth: User access control, encryption, audit logging, input validation, principle of least privilege.
mustNotMiss: Database security layers: OS security, network (firewall, SSL), MySQL users/privileges, application-level checks. Think: Who can connect? What can they do? What's logged? What if credentials leak?
topics.description: Introduction to Database Security

topics.name: Creating a User
learningTip: CREATE USER 'name'@'host' IDENTIFIED BY 'password'. Host restricts connection source: localhost, %, specific IP.
mustNotMiss: CREATE USER 'app'@'
%' IDENTIFIED BY 'StrongPass123!'; Host patterns: 'localhost' (local only), '%' (anywhere - avoid), '
%' (subnet). USE mysql_native_password or caching_sha2_password for auth plugin.
topics.description: Master Creating a User for effective SQL queries

topics.name: Viewing Users
learningTip: SELECT user, host FROM mysql.user. SHOW GRANTS FOR user@host shows privileges.
mustNotMiss: Query mysql.user table for user list. SHOW GRANTS FOR 'app'@'localhost'; shows exactly what user can do. Regular audit: who has access? Are old accounts removed? Any overly permissive grants?
topics.description: Virtual tables with Viewing Users

topics.name: Dropping Users
learningTip: DROP USER 'name'@'host'. Removes user and all grants. User sessions are not immediately terminated.
mustNotMiss: Before dropping, check dependencies: stored procedures defined with DEFINER, views, events. May need to reassign or recreate. Best practice: disable first (revoke privileges, change password) then drop after confirming no issues.
topics.description: Master Dropping Users for effective SQL queries

topics.name: Changing Passwords
learningTip: ALTER USER 'name'@'host' IDENTIFIED BY 'newpassword'. Or SET PASSWORD for current user.
mustNotMiss: For current user: SET PASSWORD = 'newpassword'; Enforce password policies: REQUIRE SSL, PASSWORD EXPIRE INTERVAL 90 DAY, PASSWORD HISTORY 5. Use strong passwords: length, complexity, uniqueness.
topics.description: Master Changing Passwords for effective SQL queries

topics.name: Granting Privileges
learningTip: GRANT privilege ON database.table TO user@host. Privileges: SELECT, INSERT, UPDATE, DELETE, CREATE, DROP, ALL.
mustNotMiss: Principle of least privilege: Give only what's needed. GRANT SELECT, INSERT ON myapp.* TO 'app'@'localhost'; Column-level: GRANT SELECT (id, name) ON myapp.users TO 'reporting'@'localhost'; Avoid GRANT ALL ON *.*.
topics.description: Master Granting Privileges for effective SQL queries

topics.name: Viewing Privileges
learningTip: Views are saved queries that act like virtual tables. Great for abstraction and security.
mustNotMiss: Views don't store data - they run the underlying query each time. Understand updatable vs read-only views.
topics.description: Virtual tables with Viewing Privileges

topics.name: Revoking Privileges
learningTip: REVOKE privilege ON database.table FROM user@host. Mirrors GRANT syntax.
mustNotMiss: REVOKE DELETE ON myapp.* FROM 'app'@'localhost'; Note: Revoking doesn't affect active sessions until reconnection. To see current grants: SHOW GRANTS. Regular privilege audits: who has what? Is it still needed?
topics.description: Master Revoking Privileges for effective SQL queries
